div.head: Making silver runny
div.ab: If it is for a large work, arsenic and pulverized tartar thrown into melted silver, makes the silver runny. This is enough for silver. But for subtle work, you need bronze, filings, copper, even antimony, sublimate, all neatly ground. All of this makes a mass that does not get smaller. If the plaster is good, you do not need to add crocum for silver, but one puts in more feather alum. Having therefore chosen them, take some sand, the leanest and driest you can find, that must be very well ground, like the one goldsmiths use to sand enamel, or like the one used for engraving.
